Award.AwardTitle: SMARTER Teamwork: System for Management, Assessment, Research, Training, Education, and Remediation for Teamwork

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engineering - Other (59)
Teamwork predominates in engineering education, yet the careful design and assessment of methods for students to learn teamwork skills is not widespread. Teaching teaming skills is a complex challenge, one for which most engineering faculty have not been prepared. This project is building on a successful, web-based system for assigning and assessing teaming in engineering education, expanding this resource to additional institutions and increasing the capabilities of the tool. The goals of this project are to equip students to work on teams by providing them with training and feedback, to equip faculty to manage student teams by providing them with information and tools to facilitate best practices, and to equip researchers to understand teams by broadening the system's capabilities to collect additional types of data through a secure researcher interface. The use of the teaming tools in STEM disciplines outside of engineering is also being investigated through this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2003-2007, NSF funded a project to measure how well students work in teams, and a team of researchers from engineering and management designed a system that was starting to become popular. In 2008, when 300 instructors at 100 institutions had used this new approach to manage teams, NSF provided support to scale up the project. To do that, the project team needed to provide strong proof of the quality of the measurement and tell lots of people about it.

The tool to measure teamwork was called the Comprehensive Assessment of Team-Member Effectiveness, or CATME. It has a companion tool that is used to form teams called Team-Maker. These two tools formed the basis for what became known as the SMARTER Teamwork system. As a whole, the system is designed to (1) equip students to work in teams, (2) equip faculty to manage student teams, and (3) equip researchers to understand teams.

During this expansion, the project team has not just advertised the system to a larger audience -- the team has worked to transform the system so that it addresses the needs of an ever larger commuunity.

The rapid growth of the number of users of the system reveals that these tools meet a critical need. The system has been used by over 374,000 unique students of more than 7500 instructors at over 1350 institutions. The rate of growth of the user base continues to increase. In the past year, we have added an average of more than 200 new faculty users each month. The research team has been honored in multiple venues for the results of this project.
